title: How to write a conclusion for a trip experience - Quora

response.answer_text: Most conventional advice about how to write conclusions (“tell ’em what you told ’em,” or restate your main argument “in conclusion,” etc.) is terrible. No one ever wrote a memorable or resonant conclusion by writing “in conclusion, here’s another way of saying what I’ve already said four times.” Instead, situate your argument in a broader context. Think about how your argument applies to your reader, to their community, to their country, to their life on earth as a human being. Why should they care? What’s in it for them, to listen to what you’ve been saying and take it to heart? Why does it really matter? More here: How to Write Conclusions That Don’t Suck

You didn't say what you are writing; if you are writing a novel, the third and final act is about 25% of your story and should be devoted to closing your story. By the end of the third act you should have accounted for all your main characters, what happened to them, and how the protagonist won over the antagonist and the conflicts. You need to 'tie up' all the story's conflicts and loose ends. K.M. Weiland's writing guide, 'Structuring Your Novel', and others, will show you what you need to do. It's not possible to get sufficient help here without being intimately involved in your story. You wrote it and only you can close it out. Some authors write the last sentence first. I knew how my story would start and end before I started writing. What I wasn't sure about was who or what the antagonist was. But it all worked out.
